Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Situation2: The partner is grieving the sudden loss of a close family member.
Story: I sat on the edge of my bed, phone buzzing in my hand. My stepbrother’s text glowed on the screen: “Can you come talk? I really need you.” He’d just found out his dad—my stepdad—was seriously ill, and I knew he was falling apart. I was supposed to be there for him, the one person he could lean on when things got rough. But as I stared at his message, my phone vibrated again. This time, it was my boyfriend. “I can’t stop crying. Can you come over?” His grandmother had passed away that morning, and he was shattered. I could hear the pain in his voice, and I knew he needed me, too. My chest tightened as I looked between the two messages. Both of them were counting on me to be their anchor, to help them through their grief. I felt pulled in two directions, guilt gnawing at me no matter which way I turned. I wanted to be there for both, but I knew I couldn’t split myself in half. My hands shook as I tried to decide who needed me more, my heart aching for both of them.
